existing_features.title: Build a playable, single-player story adventure game inspired by the Ramayana (Ramayan), featuring an original retelling structure (chapters/episodes), with original wording and presentation (do not copy text from any copyrighted adaptation).

Implement core gameplay loop: chapter progression with player choices that affect at least one tracked game state variable (e.g., virtue/honor score, resources, allies) and a simple interactive challenge per chapter (e.g., a short combat/skill mini-game) so the experience is more than a visual novel.
Add save/load of player progress (current chapter and key state variables) using the Internet Computer backend so a player can return and continue later.

Provide a coherent, distinctive visual theme for the game UI (typography, colors, layout, and component styling) inspired by classical Indian epic aesthetics (e.g., parchment, carved motifs, warm earth tones) and apply it consistently across all screens. Avoid default blue/purple styling.

Add generated static image assets (backgrounds/illustrations) and render them from the frontend as static files (no backend image serving). Place generated files under frontend/public/assets/generated and reference them in the UI.

Add a mission/level completion structure so each chapter functions as a complete mission with clear objectives and an explicit "Mission Complete" state before the player can continue to the next chapter.

Update the game state model and reducer logic to track mission objective completion per chapter, including whether the player has made a choice for the current chapter (not just challenge completion).
Extend save/load so mission/level completion progress is preserved across sessions, including mission objective completion needed to determine whether the current chapter is complete.
Update chapter content definitions to support mission objective labeling (user-facing text) in English, without changing the existing chapter narratives unless required for objective display.

Replace the existing Ramayana-inspired chapter content with an original, English, street-fighting storyline using the current chapter/mission structure (chapters with narratives, choices, objectives, and a challenge), keeping the same total number of chapters unless additional chapters are necessary for coherence.

Update the start screen and chapter screen user-facing text to match the street fighting theme (game title, descriptions, labels, and end-of-game messaging) while keeping the existing navigation and save/load entry points intact.

Retheme the UI from the current parchment/epic aesthetic to a gritty urban street-fighting aesthetic (e.g., concrete/metal textures, high-contrast neutrals, punchy accent colors) and apply it consistently across start screen, HUD, cards, buttons, and mission status UI; do not introduce a default blue/purple look.

Add a street-fight-appropriate interactive challenge used by at least one chapter (e.g., a simple combo/quick-time or timing-based brawl mini-game) and integrate it into the existing challenge selection/rendering flow so mission completion can depend on it.

Generate and wire up new static image assets for the street fighting game (title background, chapter backgrounds, and character/scene illustration set) by placing them under `frontend/public/assets/generated` and updating all references so no missing-asset paths remain.

Add a small set of predefined playable characters (at least 3) to the street-fighting game, each with a stable characterId, display name, short bio blurb, and portrait image path, and store these definitions in a dedicated frontend module so they can be reused across screens.

Implement a character selection UX so the player can choose a character before starting a new game, and ensure the selected character is clearly shown as selected and can be changed before confirming.

Persist the selected character for authenticated users by extending the backend user profile to include the chosen characterId, and update the profile setup flow to collect both fighter name and character selection.

Integrate the selected character into gameplay UI by displaying the chosen character (name and portrait) in the HUD and/or chapter screen, without changing the existing story structure (chapters/choices/challenges).
Ensure the selected character is preserved across Save/Load by including characterId in the saved progress payload and restoring it when loading progress.

Render any newly generated character portrait assets as static files under frontend/public/assets/generated and reference them from the character definitions and UI so there are no missing asset paths.
